text: This morning, as we're here in Matthew chapter number 15, I want to examine an interaction that takes place between a desperate mother and the Lord Jesus Christ during His earthly ministry. Obviously, as we read through the Gospel accounts, we have the privilege of reading about the life and ministry of our wonderful Savior, the Lord Jesus Christ. Many times throughout the Gospel accounts, we have the privilege of seeing those interactions that are captured in the ways in which the Lord ministered in individual families and to individuals. We find that there are many times in which He ministered to great multitudes of people. There are times in which the Gospel accounts record for us the interactions between the Lord and the religious leaders, the scribes and the Pharisees and the Sadducees and all of those interactions. And there's so much content that is given to us in the four Gospel records with regard to the life and ministry of the Lord Jesus Christ. And we find in the text of Scripture that we're looking at this morning that this particular interaction is recorded by Matthew and by Mark. And we'll look at both passages of Scripture this morning. Let me read for you the Matthew passage first, and we'll hold our spot here, and then look over at the Mark passage. And I will let you know at the very beginning of the message that we will be going back and forth between Matthew and Mark, so you will want to hold your place in each of those locations so that you can quickly pass back and forth to look at the passage. I will also mention this, the interaction that is recorded for us in these two passages of Scripture is an interaction between a desperate mother and the Lord Jesus Christ. So there's obviously going to be some application to mothers, in particular dealing with Mother's Day. But we also find that the truth that is given in this passage of Scripture is truth that is applicable for every child of God. And I hope that it will be a blessing to you this morning. Matthew chapter number 15, begin looking in verse number 21. The Bible says, Then Jesus went thence, and departed into the coast of Tyre and Sidon. And behold, a woman of Canaan came out of the same coast, and cried unto him, saying, Have mercy on me, O Lord, thou Son of David! My daughter is grievously vexed with a devil. But he answered her not a word. And his disciples came and besought him, saying, Send her away, for she crieth after us. But he answered and said, I am not sent, but unto the lost sheep of the house of Israel. Then came she, and worshipped him, saying, Lord, help me. But he answered and said, It is not meet to take the children's bread, and to cast it to dogs. And she said, Truth, Lord! Yet the dogs eat of the crumbs which fall from their master's table. Then Jesus answered and said unto her, O woman, great is thy faith! Be it unto thee, even as thou wilt. And her daughter was made whole from that very hour. We know that it really happened. And we now, almost 2,000 years later, are rejoicing in the work that was accomplished on this day. But as we begin to examine the passage of Scripture, we begin to notice what this desperate mother recognized and what she requested, what she received. Oh, how we're challenged in our own walk with Thee today. Oh God, it's our prayer that they'd get that settled today. They would not allow for another moment to go by without knowing for sure that heaven is their home. God, help us to be mindful of the fact that You have all power. There's nothing beyond Your control. Nothing too difficult for Thee. Oh, but you don't understand my child. You don't understand God. And I don't say that without any concern or without any compassion. I simply say it because it's true. Our God is able. Our God is able. Oh Lord, I pray that You'd help us. Help us to depend upon Thee. Help us to seek Thee. In the moment of invitation and the quietness of the moment, Lord, I pray that You'd work in my heart and the hearts of those that are present, those that have tuned in via live stream. God, that You would do a work that we'd sit back and say, look at what God did. That You alone would be glorified. Well, thank You for all that You'll do. For it's in Christ's name we pray.

segments.text: This morning, as we're here in Matthew chapter number 15, I want to examine an interaction
that takes place between a desperate mother and the Lord Jesus Christ during His earthly
ministry.
Obviously, as we read through the Gospel accounts, we have the privilege of reading about the
life and ministry of our wonderful Savior, the Lord Jesus Christ.
Many times throughout the Gospel accounts, we have the privilege of seeing those interactions
that are captured in the ways in which the Lord ministered in individual families and
to individuals.
We find that there are many times in which He ministered to great multitudes of people.
There are times in which the Gospel accounts record for us the interactions between the
Lord and the religious leaders, the scribes and the Pharisees and the Sadducees and all
of those interactions.
And there's so much content that is given to us in the four Gospel records with regard
to the life and ministry of the Lord Jesus Christ.
And we find in the text of Scripture that we're looking at this morning that this particular
interaction is recorded by Matthew and by Mark.
And we'll look at both passages of Scripture this morning.
Let me read for you the Matthew passage first, and we'll hold our spot here, and then look
over at the Mark passage.
And I will let you know at the very beginning of the message that we will be going back
and forth between Matthew and Mark, so you will want to hold your place in each of those
locations so that you can quickly pass back and forth to look at the passage.
I will also mention this, the interaction that is recorded for us in these two passages
of Scripture is an interaction between a desperate mother and the Lord Jesus Christ.
So there's obviously going to be some application to mothers, in particular dealing with Mother's
Day.
But we also find that the truth that is given in this passage of Scripture is truth that
is applicable for every child of God.
And I hope that it will be a blessing to you this morning.
Matthew chapter number 15, begin looking in verse number 21.
The Bible says,
Then Jesus went thence, and departed into the coast of Tyre and Sidon.
And behold, a woman of Canaan came out of the same coast, and cried unto him, saying,
Have mercy on me, O Lord, thou Son of David!
My daughter is grievously vexed with a devil.
But he answered her not a word.
And his disciples came and besought him, saying, Send her away, for she crieth after us.
But he answered and said, I am not sent, but unto the lost sheep of the house of Israel.
Then came she, and worshipped him, saying, Lord, help me.
But he answered and said, It is not meet to take the children's bread, and to cast it
to dogs.
And she said, Truth, Lord!
Yet the dogs eat of the crumbs which fall from their master's table.
Then Jesus answered and said unto her, O woman, great is thy faith!
Be it unto thee, even as thou wilt.
And her daughter was made whole from that very hour.
Turn to the book of Mark, if you will, in chapter number 7.
Mark chapter number 7.
Look at verses 24 through 30.
Record the same interaction.

7, beginning in verse number 24.

and entered into a house, and would have no man know it, but he could not be hid.

be hid.
